text:
Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Discussing Solutions and Strategies

Gather the students' ratio statements from the Initial Challenge. It would be helpful to display them for the whole class to see, such as on large chart paper and/or in a gallery walk. Ask students to analyze the ratios. You can revisit the characterisitics of ratios that you discussed in the previous problem.

Suggested Questions

  • Who has a ratio statement for the large box?
  • Who has a ratio statement for the small box?
  • Do you agree that these are ratios?

• Answer will vary. Students may write ratios about the boxes or across the boxes. Display examples from many groups.
  • Answer will vary. Students may write ratios about the boxes or across the boxes. Display examples from many groups.
  • Answer will vary. Discuss any that students are questioning. Have students justify their reasoning.

Asking students to restate how another person chose their ratio statement can help solidify understanding of ratio statements. (Language)

  • Which ratios are equivalent?
  • Which ratios are part-to-part?
  • Which ratios are part-to-whole?
  • How can I change a part-to-part ratio to make it a part-to-whole ratio?
  • How can I change a part-to-whole ratio to make is a part-to-part ratio?

• Answers will vary. Have students justify their reasoning. Encourage pictures and diagrams to communicate and justify their reasoning.
  • Answer will vary.
  • Answer will vary. It may help to tell them that these typers of ratio comparisons compare one quantity to "all.")
  • Total the quantities, and make tat total one of the quantities in the ratio.
  • Subtract the part from the whole to find the other quantity. Then, write a comparison statement using the two parts.

Making the Mathematics Explicit

Discuss each of the claims in What If...? Situation A. You may want to use Learning Aid 1.3: Cupcake Claim Cards to display and take notes on each claim as you discuss them.

Suggested Question

  • Let's look at Onie's claim. Is the statement true? Is it a ratio>

In the discussion, confirm that students see the following:

Onie's claim is a ratio that compare the part of the box that is green cupcakes (8) to the total (whole) box (18).

Now What Do Students Know?

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know? Questions.

See answers to the problem for more information about the strategies and embedded mathematics.

Reflecting on Student Learning

  • Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
    • What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know? Question?
      • Where did my students get stuck?
      • What strategies did they use?
      • What breakthroughs did my students have today?
    • How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
    • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this unit? The next unit?
